title: Dutton open to beefing up foreign interference laws
text:
"We anticipate the most capable foreign intelligence services will adapt their behaviour over time to circumvent the new legislation," the report said.

Mr Dutton said the laws were effective and it was a "statement of the obvious" that some foreign intelligence services would try to circumvent the laws given that was the tradecraft of espionage.

"Leave it to the experts and if they have recommendations to make in relation to strengthen the legislation, we would be very happy to hear that," he said.

Mr Dutton roused Beijing's ire last week after he accused the Chinese Communist Party of orchestrating cyber attacks, the theft of intellectual property and trying to curb academic freedom.

Former ASIO chief Duncan Lewis, who retired last month but wrote the forward to the 2018-19 annual report, said the higher demand on ASIO on foreign interference matters was stretching its resources.

"With the terrorist threat showing no signs of significantly decreasing, ASIO has limited scope to redirect internal resources to address the increasing gap between demand for our counter-espionage and foreign interference advice and our ability to furnish this assistance," Mr Lewis wrote.

Mr Dutton denied national security was being put at risk because ASIO lacked sufficient money, saying funding to the agency was increasing every year and staff numbers were growing.

"We have more demands on our intelligence services and law enforcement agencies than ever before," Mr Dutton said.

"We'll continue to put more money into the agencies each and every year. Every agency head across the Commonwealth wants more money into their agency, and every minister wants more money into their departments and their agencies."

In its report, ASIO also flagged that the threat of violence by right-wing extremists was also on the rise.
description: The Home Affairs Minister also insists ASIO has enough money to do its job of protecting Australians.
